Atrial fibrillation , hypertension , epistaxis and history of cerebrovascular accident . Ventriculostomy placement on 7/15/98 . ASSOCIATED PROCEDURES : HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS : Mr. A was a 74-year-old right handed white male with a history of left middle cerebral artery cerebrovascular accident who on July 15th was asleep and awoke at approximately 1:00 AM with the worst headache of his life . Per his wife , the patient had been in his regular state of health except for complaints of a bifrontal severe headache . Per his wife , he was otherwise without any symptoms . He was taken first to Vaila Medical Center where he arrived at about 3:00 AM and a CT scan showed ? basal subarachnoid hemorrhage and hydrocephalus . He was loaded with Dilantin , placed on Decadron and transferred to the Ph University Of Medical Center . Remarkable for cerebrovascular accident in 1994 . PHYSICAL EXAMINATION : He was found to be an obese male with eyes closed . He was vomiting and sleepy . His mental status exam showed him to be very sleepy and he moved to sternal rub and loud voice . He was oriented to his name , Ph University Of Medical Center and 1997 and was able to follow simple commands . His motor exam showed a slight right drift and he was not cooperative with cerebellar testing . His physical examination also showed pupils at 3-2 mm. bilaterally and he blinked to threat . SUMMARY OF LABORATORY AND RADIOLOGIC EXAMINATIONS : He had significant hydrocephalus with a small intraventricular hemorrhage . Mr. A was admitted to the Neurosurgery Service with a diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage and hydrocephalus . He was found to be unable to protect his airway , so was intubated in the emergency room . His anticoagulation was immediately reversed with FFP and he received several additional units of FFP during the hospital course . He had a cerebral angiogram performed on July 15th which was unrevealing . It showed no aneurysm and no dissection and no shunting lesions . He had a ventriculostomy placed by the Neurosurgery Service on July 15th . Mr. A was transferred to the Neuroscience Intensive Care Unit on July 15th . Neurologically , his lesions were inoperable , but he received treatment with Dilantin and the ventriculostomy tube to control his intracranial pressure . His neurological exam deteriorated over the first week of admission to the extent that he was at times responsive to voice by opening his eyes , but was not able to follow commands . He moved his left side more than his right side in response to stimulation . Cardiovascularly , he developed atrial fibrillation and hypertension during the hospital course and was managed by Dr. Gach of Cardiology . Infectious Disease issues included serial fevers of unknown source . Cultures from multiple sites never grew out any organisms . He was on antibiotics for several days while in Intensive Care . Gastrointestinally , he was unable to tolerate tube feeds and was started on total parenteral nutrition . Pulmonary wise , he was maintained on a ventilator throughout the hospital course until the day of expiration . Mr. A 's neurologic condition was stable at the baseline exam as described above . His family had a meeting with Dr. Liftjesc , Dr. Telshey Vital , and Dr. Tineara Rhalt of the Neurosurgical ICU . This meeting took place on July 30th from 10:00 AM until approximately noon . They wished that he be extubated and that all medical treatment except for comfort measures be pursued . Shortly thereafter , his arterial line was removed . Following this , at approximately 2:05 PM , his endotracheal tube was removed . Mr. A immediately became bradycardic and desaturated . At 2:10 PM on July 30th , he expired . Mr. A , was immediately notified . She refused an autopsy and agreed to donation of needed organ or tissue . The Ebeairs Baxt Insum General Hospital was contacted .
